SELECT COUNT(*) FROM customers WHERE Country = “Mexico”, (how many customers from Mexico)

Default mathfunctions: SUM, COUNT, AVG, MAX, MIN

SELECTAVG(column_name) as new_name FROM table_name

SELECTStore, SUM(Amount) FROM Sales_History GROUP BY Store HAVING SUM(Amount) >200

CREATE TABLEPersons ( PersonID int NOT NULL, LastName varchar(255) NOT NULL, FirstNamevarchar(255), CONSTRAINT uc_PersonID UNIQUE(PersonID, LastName)); OR CONSTRAINTpk_PersonID PRIMARY KEY (PersonID, LastName)

CREATE TABLE Orders(O_Id int NOT NULL, OrderNo int NOT NULL, PersonID int, PRIMARY KEY (O_Id) CONSTRAINTfk_PerOrders FOREIGN KEY (P_Id) REFERENCES Persons(P_Id))

INSERT INTOPersons (‘PersonID’, ‘LastName’, ‘FirstName’)

VALUES (1,Shah, Kairavi), (2, Smith, John) etc (insert data into table)

UPDATEStudent_Attendence SET attendance = 1 WHERE name = “jane” AND date = …

DELETE FROMStudent_Attendence WHERE date = “20170109”,

SELECT name,COUNT(name)  missingCount FROMStudent_Attendence WHERE attendance = 0 GROUP BY name ORDER BY missingCountDESC (query to find out who misses class the most)

SELECT *FROM Student_Attendence WHERE date LIKE “201701%”,

SELECT *FROM Student_Attendence WHERE date IN (“20170109”, “20170111”);

DifferentJOIN – INNER JOIN (return all rows where there’s at least one match in BOTHtables), LEFT/RIGHT JOIN(Return all rows from the left/right table and the matchedrows from the right/left table), FULL JOIN(Return all rows where there is amatch in ONE of the tables).

SELECT *FROM Studen_Attendence a INNER JOIN Student_Attendence g ON g.student_id =a.student_id

Constraints –NOT NULL (column cannot store null value), UNIQUE(each row for a column hasunique value), PRIMARY KEY(Ensuresthat a column (or combination of two or more columns) have a unique identity which helps to find a particular record in tablemore easily and quickly), FOREIGN KEY (ensure referential integrity of data inone table to match values in another table)
